pages.text: Cupronickel or $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l)-$(l:materials/Nickel)nickel$(/l) (CuNi) is an alloy of $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) that contains $(l:materials/Nickel)nickel$(/l) and strengthening elements, such as $(l:materials/Iron)iron$(/l) and $(l:materials/Manganese)manganese$(/l). The $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) contents typically varies from 60 to 90 percent. (Monel metal is a $(l:materials/Nickel)nickel$(/l)-$(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) alloy that contains a minimum of 52 percent $(l:materials/Nickel)nickel$(/l).)$(p)Despite its high $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) content, cupronickel is $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) in colour. Cupronickel is highly resistant to corrosion by salt water, and

is therefore used for piping, heat exchangers and condensers in seawater systems, as well as for marine hardware. It is sometimes used for the propellers, propeller shafts, and hulls of high-quality boats. Other uses include military equipment and chemical, petrochemical, and electrical industries.$(p)Another common modern use of cupronickel is $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l)-coloured coins. For this use,

the typical alloy has 3:1 $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) to $(l:materials/Nickel)nickel$(/l) ratio, with very small amounts of $(l:materials/Manganese)manganese$(/l). In the past, true $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) coins were debased with cupronickel.
